utterance: No, Willy; an Arab never betrays a man who has eaten his salt. This man has broken bread with us ; we cannot give him up. I don't think we ought to have told about him as much as we did.

utterance: Balla, come here.
speaker: Mrs. Stafford

utterance: Hi, Mistis—

utterance: Hi, Mistis, whar is I got to go? I wuz born on dis place an' I 'spec' to die here, an' be buried right yonder
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: Dat I does.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: Y' all sticks by us, and we '11 stick by you.

utterance: Dee tell me dee got hoofs and horns

utterance: Where is it, Balla? What is it?

speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: Will they be here to-night?
speaker: Mrs. Stafford

utterance: No, marm; I don' hardly think they will. That man said they could n't travel more than thirty miles a day ; but they 'ell be plenty of 'em here to-morrow— to breakfast.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: Here,— you all come here.
speaker: Mrs. Stafford

utterance: Balla, step here.

utterance: Yes 'm, that 's so; that 's jes' what I wuz gwine do

utterance: What is it?

utterance: Where is the best place to put that?
speaker: Mrs. Stafford

utterance: Well, I declar', Mistis, that 's hard to tell, without it 's in the stable.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: They may burn that down.

utterance: That 's so ; you might bury it under the floor of the smoke-house ?

utterance: I have heard that they always look for silver there.

utterance: How would it do to bury it in the garden?
speaker: Mrs. Stafford

utterance: That 's the very place I was gwine name,
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: They can't burn that down, and if they gwine dig for it then they '11 have to dig a long time before they git over that big garden.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: I thought of the other end of the flower-bed, between the big rose-bush and the lilac.
speaker: Mrs. Stafford

utterance: That 's the very place I had in my mind.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: They won' never fine it dyah!
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: We know a good place, it 's a heap better than that. It 's where we bury our treasures when we play 'Black-beard the Pirate.'
speaker: Frank and Willy

utterance: Very well, I don 't care to know where it is until after to-morrow, any how. I know I can trust you
speaker: Mrs. Stafford

utterance: Yes'm, you know dat.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: I '11 jes' go an' git my hoe.

utterance: The garden has n't got a roof to it, has it, Unc' Balla?

utterance: Gro 'way from here, boy. That boy ain ' never done talkin ' 'bout that thing yit,

utterance: And you ain't ever given me all those chickens either
speaker: Willy

utterance: Oh, well, I 'm gwi' do it; ain't you hear me say I 'm gwine do it?
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: That 's the way we always do when we bury the treasure. Ain't it, Willy?
speaker: Frank

utterance: If a man speaks, it 's death !
speaker: Willy

utterance: Give the 'galleon* to us
speaker: Frank

utterance: No ; be off with you,
speaker: Mrs. Stafford

utterance: That 'ain 't the way, A pirate never digs the hole until he has his treasure at hand. To do so would prove him but a novice ; would n't it, Willy?
speaker: Frank

utterance: Well, I leave it all to you, my little Buc caneers. I '11 take care of the spoons and forks we use every day. I '11 just hide them away in a hole some where.
speaker: Mrs. Stafford

utterance: Look here, boys; I ain ' got time to fool with you chillem, Ain 't you hear your ma tell me she 'pend on me to bury that silver what yo' gran 'ma and gran 'pa used to eat off o'— an' don' wan' nobody to know nothin' 'bout it? An' y' all comin' here with guns, like you huntin' squ'rr'ls, an' now talMn' 'bout wadin' in the ditch!
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: But, Unc' Balla, that's the way all bucca neers do,
speaker: Frank

utterance: Yes, buccaneers always go by water.
speaker: Willy

utterance: Bookanear or bookafar,— I 'se gwine in dat garden and dig a hole wid my hoe, an' I is too ole to be wadin' in a ditch like chillern. I got the misery in my knee now, so bad I 'se sea 'eely able to stand. I don't know huccome y' all ain't satisfied with the place you' ma an' I done pick, anyways.
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: Here is the spot

utterance: Little boys!
speaker: the Major's Clinstmas presents lady

utterance: We are looking for my son; and this gentle man tells me that you live about here, and know more of the country than any one else I may meet.
speaker: the Major's Clinstmas presents lady

utterance: Do you know where any graves is ?— Yankee graves?
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: Where was your son killed, ma 'am ? Do you know that he was killed?
speaker: Uncle Balla

utterance: I do not know. We fear that he was ; but, of course, we still hope there may have been some mistake. The last seen of him was when General Sheridan went through this country, last year. He was with his company in the rear-guard, and was wounded and left on the field. We hoped he might have been found in one of the prisons; but there is no trace of him, and we fear —
speaker: the Major's Clinstmas presents lady

utterance: He was my only son, my only son— and I gave him up for the Union, and —
speaker: the Major's Clinstmas presents lady

utterance: If I could but find his grave. Even that would be better than this agonizing suspense.
speaker: the Major's Clinstmas presents lady

utterance: What was your son's name?
speaker: unkown

utterance: Why, that 's our soldier!
speaker: Frank and Willy

utterance: Do you know him?
speaker: the Major's Clinstmas presents lady

utterance: Is—? Is—?
speaker: the Major's Clinstmas presents lady

utterance: Yes, 'm. In our garden.
speaker: unkown

utterance: "Won't you come home with us? Our father  and mother will be so glad to have you,"
speaker: boys

utterance: "He was a real brave soldier,"
speaker: boys

utterance: "Oh, yes, indeed. Certainly,"
speaker: boys

utterance: "We have n't got much. We did n't Idll any  squirrels this morning. Both our guns are  broken and don't shoot very well, now."
speaker: boys

utterance: "Oh, yes, they 're big folks,"
speaker: the driver

utterance: "My son—"
speaker: the Major's Clinstmas presents lady

utterance: "I have one, too;— God alone knows where he  is,"
speaker: Mrs. Stafford

utterance: "Come here, quickly!"
speaker: boys' father

utterance: "I don't think much of this Christmas," A hatchet, a ball of string, and a hare trap is n't much.'
speaker: Ran

utterance: "I too have to do without my Christmas gift, Your father wrote me that he hoped  to spend Christmas with us, and he has not  come."
speaker: Mrs. Stafford

utterance: "Never mind; he may come yet, An axe was  just the thing I wanted, mamma,"
speaker: Bob

utterance: "And a hatchet was what I wanted, now I can make my own hare-traps."
speaker: Ran

utterance: "An' I like a broked knife,"
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "I love my dolly, and I love Santa Tlaus, an' I love my papa,"
speaker: Evelyn

utterance: "Santa Tlaus did n' turn this Trismas, but  he 's tummin' next Trismas,"
speaker: Evelyn

utterance: "And why did he not come this Christmas,  Miss Wisdom?"
speaker: Major Stafford

utterance: "Tause the Yankees would n' let him,"
speaker: Evelyn

utterance: "And why, then, should he come next year?"
speaker: Major Stafford

utterance: "Tause Crod 's goin' to make him."
speaker: Evelyn

utterance: "How do you know  this?"
speaker: Major Stafford

utterance: "Tause Grod told me,"
speaker: Evelyn

utterance: "He did? What is Santa Glaus going to  bring you?"
speaker: Major Stafford

utterance: "He 's  goin' to bring me— a— great— big— dolly— with  real sure 'nough hair, and blue eyes that will  go to sleep."
speaker: Evelyn

utterance: "She has dreamt it, There is not such a  doll as that in the Southern Gonfederacy,"
speaker: Major Stafford

utterance: "Yes, he is, 'cause I asked hiTn an' he said  he would; and Charlie "
speaker: Evelyn

utterance: "Well, what did you ask Santa Glaus for,  young man?"
speaker: Major Stafford

utterance: "For a pair of breeches and a sword,"
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "Well, upon my word! I  had no idea what a young Achilles we had here. Tou shall have them."
speaker: Major Stafford

utterance: "All right. When  I get to be a man I won't let anybody make my  mamma cry."
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "Ah! you won't?"
speaker: Major Stafford

utterance: "Nor my little sister,"
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "No; he won't let anybody make me ky,"
speaker: Evelyn

utterance: "On my word, Ellen, the fellow has some of  the old blood in him, Come here, my young knight. I had rather have  heard you say that than have won a brigadier's  wreath. Yeu shall have your breeches and your  sword next Christmas. Were I the king I should  give you your spurs. Eemember, never let any  one make your mother or sister cry."
speaker: Major Stafford

utterance: "All right,"
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "dolly that can go to sleep."
speaker: Evelyn

utterance: "What is the price of this?"
speaker: Major

utterance: "Ten dollars,"
speaker: shopkeeper

utterance: "Now show me where there is a toyshop."
speaker: Major

utterance: "I don't cry now, I am a knight, and  next Christmas I am going to be a man, 'cause  my papa 's goin' to tell Santa Claus to bring  me a pair of breeches and a sword."
speaker: Charlie

utterance: "God bless and keep my papa, and  bring him safe home, Please,  God, bless and keep Santa Tlaus, and let him  come here Trismas."
speaker: Evelyn

utterance: "Oh, mamma! they have hung  him, just because he had on those clothes ! ' '
speaker: Ran

utterance: "My Dearest Grandpapa: I want to see you very  much. I send you a Christinas gift. I made it myself. I hope to get a whole lot of dolls and other presents. I love' you. I send you all these kisses You must kiss them. Your loving little granddaughter, Ln.Y."

utterance: Colonel, I think  I shall have to continue your parole a few days  longer. I have just received information that,  by a special cartel which I have arranged, you  are to be exchanged for Colonel McDowell as  soon as he can reach the lines at this point from  Richmond ; and meantime, as we have but indif ferent accommodations here, I shall have to re quest you to consider Holly Hill as your place  of confinement. Will you be so kind as to con vey my respects to Mrs. Stafford, and to your  young hero Bob, and make good my word to  those two little commissioners of exchange, to  whom I feel somewhat committed? I wish you  a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year.

utterance: An' this from Griff O'Meara. Heaven bless her swate sowl!

utterance: Where 's my old doctor and my dolly?
speaker: Nancy Pansy

utterance: Where 's  Harry and Tom Adams?
speaker: Nancy Pansy

utterance: Oh, Jack, we ain 'gwine fine no horse down heah; dese woods is too big; he done los'. There 's a clearin' right ahead here; let 's go home.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Naik, naik
speaker: Jack

utterance: Who dat calling?
speaker: Jake

utterance: Hush! it 's a picket
speaker: Jack

utterance: Run, Jake!
speaker: Jack

utterance: TIIHE horse! tlie horse! Here he is! here he JL is !
speaker: Jack

utterance: You did n't see him, Jake?
speaker: Jack

utterance: How you gwine ketch boss in trap? 'T will take all de plank in de worl' to make a hoss-trap. Be sides, how you gwine git it heali? I ain' gwine tote it.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Wlio asked you to? I 'm going to trap Mm like they do tigers and lions.
speaker: Jack

utterance: I don' know nuttin' 'bout dem beas'es,
speaker: Jake

utterance: No, you don't, but I do.
speaker: Jack

utterance: I 've got it! I 've got it! We '11 bait him, and then catch him. Where are the axe and corn you had?
speaker: Jack

utterance: I done los' 'em,
speaker: Jake

utterance: Now you just go and find 'em
speaker: Jack

utterance: I los' 'em when dem Yankees shoot we all. I know I ain' gwine back deah, I ain' gwine have no Yankee shootin' me 'bout a old boss.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Yes, you are, I 'm going, and you 've got to go, too.
speaker: Jack

utterance: I don' keer ef you don' play wid me, I don' want play so much nohow; an' I don' want none you' bis cuit. Dee ain' white like dee use' to be.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Never mind, that was Aunt Winnie's axe you lost. I 'm going to tell her you lost it, and she '11 cut you all to pieces. I 'm mighty glad I did n't lose it.
speaker: Jack

utterance: Run, Jack ; heah dey come,
speaker: Jake

utterance: Hide in the bushes
speaker: Jack

utterance: The horse! it 's the horse.
speaker: Jack

utterance: Nor, sah, he warn' gwine 'mong dem Yankees; Yankees ketch him and shoot him. He was gwine home. Mammy 'd whup him if he did n'; she mought whup him anyway.
speaker: Jake

utterance: 'T ain't no thing but this new horse. He just wanted to see his master. I '11 put my saddle on him now, boys. I 've got him so certain, and I mean to let him know he 's got a master.
speaker: the man

utterance: That horse is loose
speaker: one of the men

utterance: I '11 go and see
speaker: another one

utterance: There 's the relief.
speaker: another

utterance: He 's loose! there 's a man on him!
speaker: the men

utterance: Halt, halt!
speaker: the picket

utterance: Halt!
speaker: the picket

utterance: My son, I want you to carry the horse back and return him to the Yankee camp.
speaker: Mrs. Stafford

utterance: Why, mamma, he 's my horse; that is, he is yours. I found him and caught him and gave him to you.
speaker: Jack

utterance: Jake 's got it in his pocket.
speaker: Jack

utterance: Yes, I got de pass.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Hi! I done los' it.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Jack, what dey gwine do wid us?
speaker: Jake

utterance: Hang you, you black little horse-stealing imp ! Cut you up into little pieces.
speaker: one of the men

utterance: Jack, I told you not to come.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Don't be scared. We will get away.
speaker: Jack

utterance: Let Jake go. or I '11 blow your brains out.
speaker: Jack

utterance: We 've got the little horse-thieves. They were coming over after another horse; but I guess we '11 break it up now.
speaker: the soldiers

utterance: Why, they are mighty little fellows to be horse-thieves.
speaker: one

utterance: They are the worst kind.
speaker: the other

utterance: Must be right bad, then, corporal, for you are pretty handy yourself.
speaker: a comrade

utterance: We are not any horse-thieves. We found this horse.
speaker: Jack

utterance: Shut up !
speaker: one of his captors

utterance: Can't they get away in there?
speaker: one man

utterance: No; there is a bolt on the outside of the door. Besides, we are aU down here.
speaker: another

utterance: How you gwine do it?
speaker: Jake

utterance: Never mind, I '11 do it.
speaker: Jack

utterance: What are those boys doin' upstairs there? They ain't tryin' to git away, yo s'pose, are they? If so, we better fetch 'em down here.
speaker: one of the men

utterance: Oh, no, 't ain't nothin' but rats. They 're fast asleep, I guess.
speaker: one of them

utterance: That war 'n't no rats. Them boys is trying to git out. I heard the window open. Go and see what they are doing.
speaker: one

utterance: You go yourself. I say it 's rats.
speaker: he

utterance: Bats! You 've got rats. I '11 go, just to show you 't ain't rats.
speaker: the other

utterance: Well, you are right for once. Must have been rats; they are both fast asleep on the floor.
speaker: Jack heard him say

utterance: What on earth was that?
speaker: some one

utterance: Jake, oh Jake, are you dead?
speaker: Jack

utterance: I dun know; b'lieve I is. Mos' dead, anyway.
speaker: Jake

utterance: No, you ain't. Is your leg broke?
speaker: Jack

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Jake

utterance: No, 't ain't. Waggle your toe; can you waggle your toe?
speaker: Jack

utterance: Yes; some, little bit.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Waggle your otlier toe— waggle all your toes.
speaker: Jack

utterance: Your leg ain't broke; you are all right. Come on.
speaker: Jack

utterance: Crawl. Come on, like Injins. It 's getting day.
speaker: Jack

utterance: Here 's where they escaped.
speaker: they

utterance: Here 's their track, where they went. They cannot have gone far. We can catch them.
speaker: another man

utterance: Run, Jake; run for the woods.
speaker: Jack

utterance: There they go! catch them!
speaker: a cry

utterance: Come on, Jake; here they come.
speaker: Jack

utterance: Come on, Jake; they are coming. They won't hit you— you can get over.
speaker: Jack

utterance: Help—help me!
speaker: Jake

utterance: I Ve got you.
speaker: Jack

utterance: Don't—
speaker: Jack

utterance: He 's all right.
speaker: some one

utterance: I went back after Jake.
speaker: Jack

utterance: Yes, you did, like a man. We saw you.
speaker: an officer

utterance: Mother, we carried the horse back, but—
speaker: Jack

utterance: He is just outside the door; he belongs to you. His owner has presented him to you.
speaker: the same gentleman

utterance: To me and Jake! Where is Jake ?
speaker: Jack

utterance: poking about
speaker: Mrs. O'Meath

utterance: What you squeezin' dat dog so for? Stop dat ! Don ' you heah him crying ?
speaker: Mammy

utterance: 'T ain' any use havin' a dog if you carn't squeeze him
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Ain't you got no better sense 'n to be chawing my frock, dog? Ef you ain't, I gwine teach you better.
speaker: Mammy

utterance: Eoy, Eoy! Here, Eoy, come here.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: What 's that dirty dog doin' in this room?
speaker: Mrs. O'Meath

utterance: Oh, Mrs. O'Meath, please, madam, let me keep him. He came from heaven. I have n't anything, and I want him so. Hush ! You must not bark at Mrs. O'Meath. Hush, sir!
speaker: Molly

utterance: Not I, indeed. Out he goes. 'Ave I to be slavin' meself to death for the two of you? It is n't enough for the wan of you, and him bark in' at me like that.
speaker: Mrs. O'Meath

utterance: Oh, Mrs. O'Meath, please, madam! I will sew for you all my life, and do everything you want me to do, 0 God, don't let her take him away from me!
speaker: Molly

utterance: a loud-mouthed little baste
speaker: Mrs. O'Meath

utterance: teach him manners by choking the red, noisy tongue out his empty head.
speaker: Mrs. O'Meath

utterance: Eoy, Eoy! Here, Eoy, come here.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: How do you do?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Oh, very well, thank you, My dog has come back.
speaker: Molly

utterance: Why, is he your dog, too? He 's my dog
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Is he? I thought he was mine. I hoped he was. He came in one day, and I did n't know he belonged to anybody but me. I had been lying here so long I hoped he would always stay with me.
speaker: Molly

utterance: I will give him to you
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Oh, will you? Thank you so much.
speaker: Molly

utterance: Have you got anything to feed him on?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Yes, some bones I put away for him.
speaker: Molly

utterance: I have a roll here I will give him
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Can I have a little piece of it?
speaker: Molly

utterance: Have n't had any breakfast, and nearly  lunch time! Are you going to wait till  luncheon?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: 'Luncheon?' What is that?
speaker: Molly

utterance: I get dinner generally; but I am afraid I  may n't get any to-day. Mrs. O'Meath is  drunk.
speaker: Molly

utterance: Here, take this; eat all of it. I will get my  mother to send you some dinner right away,  and every day.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: What is your name?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Molly.
speaker: Molly

utterance: Molly what?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: I don't believe I 've got any other name. My mother was named Mary.
speaker: Molly

utterance: Where is she?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: She 'sdead.
speaker: Molly

utterance: And your father?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Kilt! 'T least I reckon he  was. Mrs. O'Meatli says lie was. I don't know  whether he 's dead or not.
speaker: Molly

utterance: Who is Mrs. O'Meath?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: She 's the lady 't takes care of me.
speaker: Molly

utterance: Your nurse?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: N— I don't know. She ain't my mother.
speaker: Molly

utterance: Well, she don't take very good care of you,  I think.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Oh! she 's drunk to-day.
speaker: Molly

utterance: Drunk!
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Yes. She '11 be all right to-morrow.
speaker: Molly

utterance: What is that?
speaker: Molly

utterance: What? This rose?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: A rose!
speaker: Molly

utterance: Oh I  I never saw one before.
speaker: Molly

utterance: Never saw a rose before 1 Why, our gar den and yard are full of them. I break them  all the time.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Are you a princess?
speaker: Molly

utterance: No. A princess!
speaker: Mildred

utterance: You can have it.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Oh! For my own? My very own?
speaker: Molly

utterance: Oh! I never thought I should have a rose  for my own, for my very own.
speaker: Molly

utterance: In the whole world?
speaker: Molly

utterance: Yes, in the whole world.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: I would rather  have that bird out there in the cage.
speaker: Molly

utterance: Would you?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Well, I will ask my mamma to give me  some money to buy it for you. I 've got to go  now.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Here, take this.
speaker: Molly

utterance: Why, how beautiful! Where did you get  it ? It would just fit one of my new dolls.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: I made it.
speaker: Molly

utterance: You did? I wish I could make anything  like that.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Would you mind something? Would you let me kiss you?
speaker: Molly

utterance: Thank you.
speaker: Molly

utterance: Good-bye. I will come again.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Oh ! will you I Thank you.
speaker: Molly

utterance: Do you know  Mrs. Johnson?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Why, I am one Mrs. Johnson. Whom do you mean?
speaker: Mrs. Johnson

utterance: The lady that has the mocking-bird.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: I have a mocking-bird.
speaker: Mrs. Johnson

utterance: Have you? I mean the lady that has a  mocking-bird and won't sell it.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: What do you know about it?
speaker: Mrs. Johnson

utterance: I wanted to buy it.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: I am sorry I could not sell it to you. The bird is all the com pany I have, and besides I don't think it is  well. It has not been singing much lately.
speaker: Mrs. Johnson

utterance: Has n 't it ?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: I wanted it  for Molly. She wants it.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Who is Molly?
speaker: Mrs. Johnson

utterance: The little crippled girl that lives aroimd  that way. She pointed. She lies at a win dow away, way up. You can almost see her out  of your window where the cage hangs. She saw  the bird from her window where she lies and  that 's the reason she wants it.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: You can have the bird.
speaker: Mrs. Johnson

utterance: Wait, I will get it.
speaker: Mrs. Johnson

utterance: But I have n't any money.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: I don't want any money.
speaker: Mrs. Johnson

utterance: But I can send it to you.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: I don't want &ny; I give it to you.
speaker: Mrs. Johnson

utterance: Do you think mamma  would mind it?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Not if she ever had a crippled child.
speaker: Mrs. Johnson

utterance: She had. But I 'm well now.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Oh, Mildred, is it—?
speaker: Molly

utterance: Where shall I put it? He  looks droopy, but Mrs. Johnson says he used  to sing all the time. He is not hungry, because  he has f6ed in the cage. I don't know what is  the matter with him.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: I do.
speaker: Molly

utterance: Never mind. It is only a minute  more, and there will be the fields and the sky.
speaker: Molly

utterance: Oh!
speaker: Mildred

utterance: There! At last!
speaker: Molly

utterance: This is the little girl who turned the bird  loose.
speaker: Mildred's mother

utterance: Mildred,
speaker: Molly

utterance: Well, what is it?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Do you think my mother will know me  when I get to Heaven? I was so little when  she went away.
speaker: Molly

utterance: Just so.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Molly, I wonder if that is  not your mocking-bird?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: I think maybe he went to Heaven that day,  to my mother.
speaker: Molly

utterance: And told your mother that you set him  free?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Mildred, I am very happy. If  I had all the money in the world, do you know  what I would do with it?
speaker: Molly

utterance: No, What?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: I would buy up all the birds in the world  that are in cages— every one— and set them  free.
speaker: Molly

utterance: Mildred, what is Easter?
speaker: Molly

utterance: Why, Easter was the time when—
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Why, it 's  the time when you have nice,  things— a new dress and don't have to give up  butter or candy, or any thing you want to eat —  don 't you know ?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Why, it 's  the day Christ rose from the dead— Don't you  know?
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Is that a fairy tale?
speaker: Molly

utterance: No, of course not ; it 's the truth.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Oh! I was in hopes it was a fairy tale. Tell me about it.
speaker: Molly

utterance: And did he sure 'nough come back— what  you call rise again?
speaker: Molly

utterance: And where is He now?
speaker: Molly

utterance: He went back up to Heaven.
speaker: Mildred

utterance: Can He send back anybody he wants?
speaker: Molly

utterance: Then I 'm going to ask Him to send back  my mother to me. I did not know  about Him. I always asked God; but I never  thought He would do it. I always thought He  had too much to do to think about a poor little  thing like me— except once. I asked Him not to  let Mrs. 'Meath take Eoy and He did n't. But  I never asked that other one. Maybe that 's the  reason He never did it before. He '11 know  about it and maybe He '11 do it, because He was  a little child too once, and He must know how  bad I want her.
speaker: Molly

utterance: Now, I 'm going to see if He '11 do it. I 've asked Him real hard three times,  and if He won't do it for that I ain't ever goin' to ask Him no more.
speaker: Molly

utterance: My baby— !
speaker: Mrs. Johnson

utterance: Mother?
speaker: Molly

utterance: Mother!
speaker: Molly
